questions.question: What new management system does ISO 42001 introduce?
Which lifecycle does ISO 42001 expect organizations to manage?
questions.answer: The entire AI system lifecycle from conception to retirement must be governed.

questions.question: What governance element is emphasized for responsible AI in ISO 42001?
questions.answer: Documented accountability with human oversight of AI outcomes.
options: Fully autonomous decision making without humans.

questions.question: Which document records the scope, policies, and procedures of the Artificial Intelligence Management System?
questions.answer: The AIMS manual consolidates scope, policies, processes, and continual improvement commitments.

questions.question: How does ISO 42001 expect organizations to handle AI-related risks?
questions.answer: They must identify, assess, and treat AI risks within the same risk management cycle used across the management system.
options: Delegate all risk decisions to vendors.
Apply the AIMS risk management cycle of identification, assessment, treatment, and monitoring.
Rely solely on regulators to determine risk levels.

questions.question: What does ISO 42001 say about data used for AI training and inference?
questions.answer: Data acquisition, preparation, and retention must be governed with documented controls to maintain integrity and privacy.
options: Data governance is optional once models are deployed.
Data collection and preparation require defined controls to preserve integrity and privacy.
Vendors handle all data responsibilities automatically.

questions.question: Which activity supports continual improvement within an AIMS?
questions.answer: Periodic internal audits and management reviews evaluate AI objectives, incidents, and opportunities to refine controls.
options: Waiting for certification bodies to report issues.
Conducting internal audits and management reviews focused on AI objectives.
Relying on marketing campaigns for feedback.
